poem:
### Pest Control 

An autumn chill returns the unwanted:  
tiny feet patrolling the night,  
winged trespassers inspecting corners,  
as if they had invitations permissible,  
entitlement to our warmth under eaves,  
until you remind them gently,  
with a whisper of steel wool,  
a sweep of sealed entryways,  
that refuge is a word for others,  
but not for the likes of them.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rats! How to banish rodents, bedbugs and other pests from your home Block entry This is the time of year when unwanted visitors start making their way into our invitingly warm homes. We all have different tolerance levels but most of us don’t want rodents and bugs roaming round. The best way to avoid having to deal with them is by taking precautions to prevent their arrival in the first place. This will, of course,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
